metadata.titleEn: Sporopollen analysis data set of typical laminar lakes in Qinghai Tibet Plateau (350-2006)
metadata.description: This data set comes from papers: Cui, A.N., Lu, H.Y., Liu, x.q., Shen, C.M., Xu, D.K., Xu, b.q., Wu, n.q., 2021. Tibetan Plateau precision modulated by the periodically coupled western and Asian Mongolia. Geophysical research letters, 48, Based on the advantage of accurate dating of the annual laminar sediments of the lake Kusai in the northern Tibetan Plateau, the authors analyzed the changes of plant sporopollen species in the area around the lake Kusai in the past 1656 years (350-2006) with high resolution (~ 5-year resolution), Based on 735 representative soil sporopollen assemblages and meteorological interpolation data within 800 km of Lake Kusai and its surrounding areas, a high-precision sporopollen annual precipitation conversion function was established to quantitatively reconstruct the precipitation and annual mean temperature changes in the past 1656 years. This data set provides a reference for studying the past climate change law and predicting the future climate change trend of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions: File naming: the data is named after the name of the paper and stored in. CSV file, which can be opened by Excel software.

background: As the “Asian Water Tower”, the Tibetan Plateau (TP) plays a crucial role in regulating the hydro-climatology of several prominent Asian rivers, which sustain more than one-fifth of the world’s population in the neighboring countries. In recent decades, the expansion of lake areas as well as the rise of lake levels resulting from increased precipitation and melting of glaciers have been observed in the TP interior. The increased precipitation could substantially improve the ecological environment via increases in vegetation coverage and ecosystem productivity; however, it may also increase the risk of flood disasters threatening the Qinghai-Tibet Railway. Observational data indicate that the water vapor in the TP interior is mainly transported by the mid-latitude Westerlies and the South Asian summer monsoon (SASM). Although the available long-term precipitation records derived from tree-rings can extend as far as 3,500 years into the past, they are from the low-elevation marginal regions of the TP, where the water vapor is supplied by the East Asian summer monsoon (EASM) or the SASM. Precipitation records spanning the past few centuries based on the accumulation rate of ice cores are also available from the high mountains in the TP, but the precipitation processes are quite different from those in the interior of the TP, although the water vapor in both cases is transported by the Westerlies and the Asian summer monsoon. Therefore, long-term precipitation records from the TP interior are important for revealing precipitation cycles on the decadal-centennial scale and their driving mechanisms. Given the wide distribution of lakes in the TP, lacustrine sediments are more suitable than the more geographically limited tree-ring and ice core records for reconstructing past variations in the hydroclimatic conditions of the TP interior. Many studies have used biotic and abiotic indicators from lake sediments as quantitative climatic proxies. Among them, fossil pollen records from lakes have been widely used to reconstruct the paleoclimate of the TP interior.
research objective: Here we present a 1,656-years (5-years-resolution) mean annual precipitation record reconstructed by fossil pollen assemblages from the annually laminated sediments of a lake in the TP interior. The relationships between these dominant multidecadal-centennial precipitation cycles and large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns can be used to interpret precipitation variability within the TP over the last 1,656 years. In addition, the results provide a context for interpreting recently increased precipitation across the TP, suggesting the possible persistence of high precipitation in the future.
methods: In September 2006, a 364-cm-long sediment core (KSS-V) was raised from the southeastern part of Kusai Lake in a water depth of 14.5 m. The sediment core was cut into blocks for lamination counting. With the assistance of an optical microscope, we counted the lamination at least three times to determine an age model, which has a ∼1% error based on replicate counts. Additionally, we measured the 210Pb, 137Cs activity of the upper 25 cm of the core and 11 AMS 14C ages to validate the robustness of the age model based on annual laminations. 364 samples with an average resolution of 5-years were used for pollen analysis. Lycopodium spores (27,560 grains/tablet) were used before acid-alkali treatment to calculate pollen concentrations. Sample residues were mounted in glycerin and analyzed using a Leica DM 750 microscope with the aid of the Pollen Flora of China. More than 400 terrestrial pollen grains were counted per sample. MAP and MAT were quantitatively reconstructed using C2 software. The modern pollen dataset was derived from previous work. An optimal transfer function was selected by minimizing the root mean-square-error of prediction (RMSEP) and maximizing the coefficient of determination (R2) between observed and predicted MAP values. In order to detect the dominant modes of the oscillations in the MAP, we first performed ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD), a noise-assisted data analysis, on the reconstructed MAP. We then calculated the power spectrum of the detrended MAP using the Morlet wavelet to characterize its statistical significance. Finally, we estimated the MAP for the next 50 years using singular spectrum analysis (SSA), a widely used nonparametric spectral estimation method in nonlinear climatic time series analysis.
dataset: Here we present a 5-years-resolution quantitative mean annual precipitation (MAP) record of the past 1,656 years from the TP interior. The record is inferred based on pollen assemblages from the annually laminated sediments of Lake Kusai and was obtained using a weighted averaging partial least squares (WA-PLS) regression model.
findings: The record reveals three dominant cycles, with lengths of ∼200-, ∼88-, and ∼60-years, associated with changes in the Westerlies and the Asian monsoon. These precipitation cycles suggest that the current high precipitation in the TP interior results from the superposition of cyclic highs in precipitation, and this trend may continue for the next several decades. The MAP reconstruction revealed three significant cycles, with periodicities of ∼200-, ∼88-, and ∼60-years, which dominated hydroclimatic variations across the TP interior. The ∼200-years cycle is attributed to the Westerlies, whereas the multidecadal cycles (∼60-years and ∼88-years) are likely related to the Asian monsoon. The record demonstrates that precipitation variations over the TP interior were mainly controlled by the Westerlies, although the Asian monsoon made a substantial contribution in summer. The periodicities in MAP during the last 1,656 years not only support the recent humidification of the TP interior, but they also enable us to predict a possible wetting trend over next decades.

Verification.Question: Can pollen analysis provide a reliable method for reconstructing past climate conditions in the Tibetan Plateau?

Disjunctive.Question: Are quantitative reconstructions of mean annual precipitation (MAP) more accurately achieved using C2 software, a weighted averaging partial least squares (WA-PLS) regression model, or another method?
Disjunctive.Answer: weighted averaging partial least squares (WA-PLS) regression model

Disjunctive.Question: Is the age model of sediment cores validated using lamination counting, 210Pb/137Cs activity measurement, AMS 14C dating, or a combination of these methods?
Disjunctive.Answer: a combination of lamination counting, 210Pb/137Cs activity measurement, and AMS 14C dating

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main data collection methods used to reconstruct past precipitation records in the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: Fossil pollen assemblages, sediment cores, lamination counting, 210Pb and 137Cs activity measurement, AMS 14C dating, pollen concentration calculation

Concept Completion.Question: Where were the sediment cores collected for analyzing precipitation cycles in the Tibetan Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to derive long-term precipitation records in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: In September 2006, a sediment core was extracted from Kusai Lake in the Tibetan Plateau. The sediment core was analyzed for pollen assemblages using lamination counting and various radiometric dating techniques, including 210Pb and 137Cs activity measurements, as well as AMS 14C dating, to build a robust age model for reconstructing mean annual precipitation over 1,656 years.

Example.Question: What is an example of using a statistical model to reconstruct past climatic conditions from lake sediments?
Example.Answer: A weighted averaging partial least squares (WA-PLS) regression model was applied to the pollen assemblages from Kusai Lake's annually laminated sediments to quantitatively reconstruct a 5-year resolution mean annual precipitation record for the past 1,656 years in the Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how modern datasets are employed to validate historical climatic reconstructions in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: Modern pollen datasets derived from previous research were utilized to develop a transfer function by minimizing prediction errors and maximizing the correlation between observed and predicted mean annual precipitation values, which were then used to validate the historical climatic reconstructions from Kusai Lake sediments.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of the pollen analysis technique used in data collection?
Feature Specification.Answer: Lycopodium spores, pollen concentrations, sample residues mounted in glycerin, microscope analysis, more than 400 terrestrial pollen grains counted per sample, MAP and MAT quantitatively reconstructed using C2 software

Feature Specification.Question: What are the significant attributes of the quantitative mean annual precipitation record derived from lacustrine sediments?
Feature Specification.Answer: 5-year resolution, 1,656-year period, inferred from pollen assemblages, WA-PLS regression model, dominant cycles linked to changes in atmospheric circulation patterns

Quantification.Question: How many pollen samples were analyzed to reconstruct the mean annual precipitation record?
What is the error margin associated with the age model used in the sediment core analysis?
How many dominant precipitation cycles were identified in the mean annual precipitation record from the Tibetan Plateau interior?

Definition.Question: What is 'fossil pollen analysis' in the context of studying historical climate variations?
Definition.Answer: Fossil pollen analysis involves examining pollen grains preserved in sediments to infer past vegetation and climate conditions. In the context of studying historical climate variations, it uses pollen assemblages from lake sediments to reconstruct past climate parameters, such as mean annual precipitation, by evaluating changes in pollen types over time.

Definition.Question: What does 'ensemble empirical mode decomposition' mean in the analysis of climatic data?
Definition.Answer: Ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD) is a data analysis method used to identify dominant modes of oscillations in time series data. It is a noise-assisted technique that helps decompose a signal into intrinsic mode functions, allowing researchers to analyze complex climatic data like reconstructed mean annual precipitation to identify significant cycles over time.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of using fossil pollen records from lake sediments compare with using tree-ring data in terms of reconstructing past climate variations in the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Fossil pollen records from lake sediments are more suitable for reconstructing past variations in the hydroclimatic conditions of the Tibetan Plateau interior due to the wide distribution of lakes and the ability to provide long-term precipitation records. In contrast, tree-ring data typically come from low-elevation marginal regions and are influenced by different water vapor sources, like the East Asian or South Asian summer monsoon.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of annually laminated sediment cores for climate reconstruction compare to other methods like ice core analysis in terms of data resolution and applicability in the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Annually laminated sediment cores offer a high-resolution (~5 years) climate reconstruction suitable for the Tibetan Plateau interior, capturing detailed precipitation cycles. In contrast, ice core analysis provides precipitation records from high mountains with processes differing from the interior, often resulting in lower resolution data influenced by different climatic factors.

Interpretation.Question: What can the identification of dominant multidecadal-centennial precipitation cycles tell us about the interactions between atmospheric circulation patterns and climatic changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The identification of dominant multidecadal-centennial precipitation cycles reveals that the interactions between atmospheric circulation patterns, such as the Westerlies and the Asian monsoon, have significantly influenced precipitation variability on the Tibetan Plateau over the past 1,656 years. These cycles help to interpret past precipitation patterns and suggest that recent increases in precipitation may persist, indicating a possible wetting trend in the future.

Interpretation.Question: How does the use of fossil pollen records from lake sediments contribute to the reconstruction of paleoclimate in the Tibetan Plateau compared to other methods like tree-rings or ice cores?
Interpretation.Answer: Fossil pollen records from lake sediments provide a more geographically comprehensive dataset for reconstructing paleoclimate conditions in the Tibetan Plateau interior. Unlike tree-rings or ice cores, which are limited by geographical spread and different precipitation processes, lake sediment-derived pollen records offer a more detailed and widespread understanding of past hydroclimatic conditions, capturing the influence of both the Westerlies and the Asian monsoon.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological steps are involved in transforming pollen assemblages from annually laminated lake sediments into a quantitative mean annual precipitation record, and what challenges might arise in this process?
Interpretation.Answer: Transforming pollen assemblages into a quantitative mean annual precipitation record involves collecting sediment cores, counting laminations to determine an age model, analyzing pollen concentrations using Lycopodium spores, and employing software like C2 for quantitative reconstruction of mean annual precipitation and temperature. Challenges in this process may include ensuring the accuracy of the age model, selecting an optimal transfer function, and dealing with uncertainties in the prediction of future precipitation trends using spectral estimation methods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the selection of pollen assemblages as proxies for reconstructing past climate conditions in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The wide distribution of lakes in the Tibetan Plateau makes lacustrine sediments suitable for reconstructing past hydroclimatic conditions. Fossil pollen records from lakes have been widely used as they provide long-term precipitation records from the interior of the Tibetan Plateau, revealing precipitation cycles on decadal-centennial scales and their driving mechanisms.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use a multi-method approach, such as the combination of 210Pb, 137Cs activity, and AMS 14C ages, in validating age models for sediment cores?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using multiple validation methods, like 210Pb, 137Cs activity, and AMS 14C ages, ensures the robustness and accuracy of age models derived from annual laminations in sediment cores. This multi-method approach helps reduce errors and increases the reliability of the chronological framework needed for high-resolution analysis of past climate conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the reliance on ensemble empirical mode decomposition and singular spectrum analysis in detecting and predicting precipitation cycles in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD) and singular spectrum analysis (SSA) are relied upon for detecting and predicting precipitation cycles because they are effective noise-assisted data analysis and nonparametric spectral estimation methods, respectively. These techniques are used to identify dominant oscillation modes in mean annual precipitation records and to predict future trends in precipitation variability.

Causal Consequence.Question: If a high-resolution pollen analysis is conducted using annually laminated lake sediments, what are the potential consequences for reconstructing long-term precipitation records?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Conducting a high-resolution pollen analysis using annually laminated lake sediments can lead to the development of precise long-term precipitation records, as it allows for the identification of multidecadal to centennial precipitation cycles and their driving mechanisms. This approach supports the understanding of past climate variability and aids in predicting future climatic trends.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for climate reconstruction accuracy when using a weighted averaging partial least squares regression model on pollen data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a weighted averaging partial least squares regression model on pollen data can enhance the accuracy of climate reconstruction by providing a quantitative mean annual precipitation record. This method helps in minimizing prediction errors and improving the correlation between observed and predicted values, offering reliable insights into historical climate patterns.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of modern pollen datasets with fossil pollen records influence the understanding of precipitation variability over centuries?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of modern pollen datasets with fossil pollen records can significantly enhance the understanding of precipitation variability over centuries by providing a robust framework for calibrating and validating past climatic conditions. This approach allows for the development of precise transfer functions, facilitating the reconstruction of historical precipitation trends and their relationship with large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective of reconstructing mean annual precipitation records using fossil pollen assemblages from lake sediments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to present a 1,656-years mean annual precipitation record to understand the precipitation variability within the Tibetan Plateau over the last 1,656 years and provide a context for interpreting recently increased precipitation, which may suggest high precipitation persistence in the future.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use a weighted averaging partial least squares regression model for estimating precipitation from pollen data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using a weighted averaging partial least squares regression model is important to provide quantitative reconstructions of mean annual precipitation based on pollen assemblages, which helps in understanding the hydroclimatic variations and dominant precipitation cycles in the Tibetan Plateau interior.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures were implemented to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the age model in the collected sediment core data from a lake in the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The age model was determined by counting laminations at least three times using an optical microscope. To validate its robustness, the 210Pb and 137Cs activity of the upper 25 cm of the core and 11 AMS 14C ages were measured, resulting in a model with approximately 1% error based on replicate counts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How were pollen concentrations calculated during the data collection process for reconstructing past climate conditions in the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Pollen concentrations were calculated using Lycopodium spores (27,560 grains/tablet) added before acid-alkali treatment. The residue was mounted in glycerin and analyzed using a Leica DM 750 microscope, with more than 400 terrestrial pollen grains counted per sample.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps were taken to reconstruct mean annual precipitation from pollen assemblages in lake sediments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Mean annual precipitation was quantitatively reconstructed using C2 software with a weighted averaging partial least squares (WA-PLS) regression model. The modern pollen dataset was derived from previous work, and an optimal transfer function was selected by minimizing the root mean-square-error of prediction (RMSEP) and maximizing the coefficient of determination (R2) between observed and predicted values.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enabled the reconstruction of historical precipitation patterns over the past 1,656 years in the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The reconstruction of historical precipitation patterns was enabled by high-resolution analysis of pollen assemblages from annually laminated sediments of Lake Kusai. The age model was validated using optical microscopy for lamination counting, activities of 210Pb and 137Cs, and AMS 14C dating, while pollen analysis involved Lycopodium spores and microscope examinations.

Enablement.Question: How do modern pollen datasets and transfer functions contribute to the accuracy of climate reconstructions in the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Modern pollen datasets and transfer functions enhance the accuracy of climate reconstructions by providing a basis for quantitative reconstruction of mean annual precipitation and mean annual temperature. An optimal transfer function is selected by minimizing the root mean-square-error of prediction and maximizing the coefficient of determination between observed and predicted values.

Enablement.Question: What methods are used to identify dominant precipitation cycles and their causes in the Tibetan Plateau over historical periods?
Enablement.Answer: To identify dominant precipitation cycles, ensemble empirical mode decomposition (EEMD) is performed on reconstructed precipitation data, followed by calculating the power spectrum using the Morlet wavelet. Singular spectrum analysis (SSA) is also utilized for nonparametric spectral estimation of climatic time series, revealing cycles related to the Westerlies and Asian monsoon.

Expectation.Question: Why might a data collection method involving fossil pollen analyses not provide the expected high-resolution insights into past climate conditions on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The resolution and accuracy of fossil pollen analyses can be affected by various factors such as the preservation state of pollen grains, the representativeness of the sediment core, and potential errors in dating models. These factors can introduce uncertainties in reconstructing climate conditions, especially in areas like the Tibetan Plateau where climatic influences are complex and multi-faceted.

Expectation.Question: What might be the reasons for the unexpected variability in precipitation cycles observed in the Tibetan Plateau datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Unexpected variability in precipitation cycles could stem from the intricate interactions between large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns, such as the Westerlies and the Asian monsoon, and local geographic and topographic factors. Additionally, the resolution of the data and the methods used to infer these cycles, like pollen analysis and spectral estimation, might also influence the observed variability.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using fossil pollen assemblages from lake sediments as a method for reconstructing long-term precipitation records?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of fossil pollen assemblages from lake sediments is considered effective for reconstructing long-term precipitation records as it provides a high-resolution (5-year interval) dataset that reflects hydroclimatic conditions over the past 1,656 years. This method enables the identification of precipitation cycles and their relationship with atmospheric circulation patterns, offering insights into past and future climate trends.
